description: From June 3, South Sudan has indefinitely suspended the issuance of COVID-19 negativity certificates to prevent forgery.
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: South Sudan has closed all schools and universities for a month, beginning March 20.
type_sub_cat: Primary Schools (generally for children ages 10 and below)

description: South Sudan has closed all schools and universities for a month, beginning March 20.
type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)

description: South Sudan has closed all schools and universities for a month, beginning March 20.
type_sub_cat: Higher education institutions (i.e. degree granting institutions)

description: From March 25, South Sudan is imposing a night-time curfew from 8 pm to 6 am throughout the country, exempting health workers, journalists, and network operators, who all can go out with a written permit.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From April 28, South Sudan is imposing a nighttime curfew from 7 pm to 6 am, exempting health workers, journalists, and network operators, who all can go out with a written permit.
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On April 28, South Sudan is ending a night-time curfew from 8 pm to 6 am throughout the country, which exempted health workers, journalists, and network operators, who all can go out with a written permit.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From May 10, South Sudan is imposing a nighttime curfew from 10 pm to 6 am, which exempts health workers, journalists, and network operators, who can all go out with a written permit.
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On May 10, South Sudan is ending a nighttime curfew from 7 pm to 6 am, which exempted health workers, journalists, and network operators, who could all go out with a written permit.
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From Jan 23, South Sudan is screening travelers at airports for symptoms of the coronavirus.
From March 13, South Sudan will halt flights with any country affected by COVID-19.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From March 23, South Sudan has halted all international flights and closed its land borders, making exceptions for food supply, emergency transport, humanitarian aid, cargo trucks, and flights landing due to technical difficulties.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From April 3, the South Sudanese state of Western Equatoria deployed police forces to 'seal' South Sudan's border with the Democratic Republic of Congo with the help of local chiefs.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: From April 27, Upper Nile State in South Sudan has intensified surveillance along the Sudanese border to prevent illegal crossings.
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description: From May 12, South Sudan has reopened airports and once again allows international flights.
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From April 22, the South Sudanese state Jonglei distributed 2,147 face masks to traders in the town of Bor.
On June 19, South Sudan's Ministry of Health "commissioned a mobile laboratory" in Eastern Equatoria "to boost coronavirus testing."
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: With support from the European Union and the World Health Organization, South Sudan organized a week of training for health workers on "principles of COVID-19 infection prevention and control (IPC) measures in the laboratory."
South Sudan has ordered a suspension of voluntary COVID-19 tests and tests for potential travellers from May 26 until June 2 so as to work through the backlog of tests.
enforcer: New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: From May 10, South Sudan's High Level Taskforce directs the Ministry of Environment "to disinfect markets, public and private transport means."
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: From April 15, South Sudan is suspending all flights and other forms of passenger transportation between states in South Sudan.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: From May 12, South Sudan is reopening airports and allowing domestic flights by all airlines.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: On March 21, South Sudan created 'the High Level Taskforce' to address COVID-19.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On May 17, South Sudan appointed the new COVID-19 Task Force to replace the High Level Taskforce in addressing coronavirus in South Sudan.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)

description: On May 17, South Sudan disbanded the High Level Taskforce, which was created to address COVID-19.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: From June 18, South Sudan has created a COVID-19 mortality surveillance team to "ensure all new deaths due to COVID- 19 are integrated into the master database".
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: From March 30, the South Sudan Ministry of Health has begun a public awareness campaign across the country about COVID-19, in cooperation with UNICEF and WHO.
From April 29, South Sudan has recommended the use of cloth face masks at all times.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: From March 16, South Sudan orders a fourteen-day quarantine for travelers who "have just arrived from countries with established local infection and transmission of COVID-19".
From March 21, any traveler entering South Sudan from a country affected by COVID-19 will be quarantined for 14 days at an isolation facility at their own expense.
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)

description: From April 20, South Sudan has ended prison visitation hours.
From April 28, South Sudan has mandated that tea and shisha stalls must shut, passenger bodabodas cannot operate, and restaurants can only offer takeaway.
From April 28, South Sudan has mandated that tea and shisha stalls must shut, passenger bodabodas cannot operate, and restaurants can only offer takeaway.
From May 10, South Sudan is allowing shops and stores to have a maximum of 5 customers inside at one time.
From May 10, South Sudan has mandated that bodabodas may only carry  1 passenger and rickshaws may only carry 2 passengers, and that "both rider and passengers must wear face masks at all times".
From May 10, South Sudan has mandated that outside of curfew hours, tea and shisha stalls can reopen, passenger bodabodas can again operate, and restaurants can operate normally.

description: From May 10, South Sudan has mandated that outside of curfew hours, tea and shisha stalls can reopen, passenger bodabodas can again operate, and restaurants can operate normally.
link: NA ; https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/340581/south-sudan-authorities-to-ease-covid-19-restrictive-measures-may-10-update-2 ; Garda ; South Sudan: Authorities to ease COVID-19 restrictive measures May 10 /update 2

description: From March 16, South Sudan has banned large social gatherings such as weddings, religious gatherings, sporting events, international conferences, and political events.
From March 27, South Sudan has suspended the training of the unified armed forces.
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 20, South Sudan ordered the release of 1400 prisoners to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in prisons. The prisoners released are to be "pre-trial detainees and prisoners who have served most of their terms."
type_sub_cat: Prison population reduced (e.g. early release of prisoners)

description: On April 20, South Sudan recommended commuting the sentences of juvenile offenders and prisoners with less than six months remaining on their sentences.
type_sub_cat: Prison population reduced (e.g. early release of prisoners)

description: Northern Bahr el Ghazal State in South Sudan temporarily released 30 prisoners "to contain the spread of the coronavirus pandemic" in prisons.
type_sub_cat: Prison population reduced (e.g. early release of prisoners)

description: From March 16, South Sudan has asked workers in offices to seat themselves 1 meter apart.
